title: High Pupil-Teacher Ratio in Preprimary Education
description: In 2017, Tanzania had a pupil-teacher ratio of 113.97 in preprimary education, indicating a significant challenge in providing adequate attention to young learners.

title: Low Investment in Energy through Public-Private Partnerships
description: In 2020, Tanzania's investment in energy through public-private partnerships was only $1.2 million, highlighting limited private sector involvement in the energy sector.

title: Minimal Patent Applications by Nonresidents
description: In 2015, Tanzania recorded just one patent application by nonresidents, reflecting a low level of foreign innovation activity in the country.

title: High Bound Rate for Manufactured Products
description: In 2021, Tanzania had a bound rate of 120% for manufactured products, indicating high tariff ceilings that could impact trade competitiveness.

title: Negative Changes in Inventories
description: In 2023, Tanzania experienced a negative change in inventories amounting to -3,192,498,275,300 LCU, suggesting economic challenges in stock management.

title: Older Starting Age for Lower Secondary Education
description: In 2023, the starting age for lower secondary education in Tanzania was 14 years, which is higher than many countries, potentially delaying educational progress.

title: Low Percentage of Labor Force with Advanced Education
description: In 2020, only 29.63% of Tanzania's working-age population had advanced education, indicating a gap in higher education attainment.

title: Low Percentage of Male Labor Force with Advanced Education
description: In 2020, 28.71% of Tanzania's male working-age population had advanced education, highlighting a gender disparity in educational attainment.

title: Low Percentage of Labor Force with Intermediate Education
description: In 2020, only 21.67% of Tanzania's working-age population had intermediate education, pointing to a need for improved educational opportunities.
